items.synopsis: Inflation has slowed down again, with consumer prices up 6 per cent over the year to June, below most economists' forecasts and reducing the chance of an RBA rate rise next week.

title.children: Inflation falls faster than expected. Has the Reserve Bank already increased interest rates too far?

image.altText: Japan fans smile and wave

items.synopsis: Former FIFA Women's World Cup winners Nadeshiko Japan are in action first up on day seven, taking on Costa Rica in Dunedin. That's followed by Spain vs Zambia in Auckland and Ireland against Canada in Perth. Follow live.

title.children: Former champions Japan score twice in two minutes to leap into early World Cup lead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two in two minutes for Nadeshiko Japan! Lovely finish from an acute angle by Aoba Fujino, who picked up a loose ball on the right, worked her way into the penalty area and then slammed the ball past Daniela Solera, who just invited the shot by leaving a gap on her near post. Fujino needed no second invitation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 27' GOAL JAPAN!

children.content: (Getty Images)
Two in two minutes for Nadeshiko Japan!

Lovely finish from an acute angle by Aoba Fujino, who picked up a loose ball on the right, worked her way into the penalty area and then slammed the ball past Daniela Solera, who just invited the shot by leaving a gap on her near post.
Fujino needed no second invitation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lovely finish from Hikaru Naomoto on the left! She capitalised on a slip in defence and raced to the edge of the penalty area on the left side, looked up, opted to shoot and nailed her finish into the corner. It's just her third goal for Japan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 25' Japan finds the opener!

children.content: Lovely finish from
Hikaru Naomoto on the left!
(Getty Images)
She capitalised on a slip in defence and raced to the edge of the penalty area on the left side, looked up, opted to shoot and nailed her finish into the corner.
It's just her third goal for Japan.

image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

items.synopsis: Consumer inflation for the June quarter falls more than expected by economists, while the IMF warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation falls to 6 per cent as interest rate hikes dampen demand, ASX surges, IMF warns of economic challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While the market is betting on a 70 per cent chance of rates staying on hold next week at 4.1 per cent because of cooling inflation, economists are torn. Nomura Australia's Andrew Ticehurst thinks the Reserve Bank will put rate hikes on ice for now because of the new data. "We now think this will provide the RBA with sufficient ammunition to deliver another “pause” at its policy meeting next week." "However, we are reluctant to call the end of the hiking cycle at this point, and think it appropriate for the market to price in another 0.25 per cent of hikes over coming months, on a balance-of-risks basis." CreditorWatch chief economist Anneke Thompson says consumers have well and truly responded to the RBA's tightening measures. " This result has reduced the chance of a further cash rate rise at the August meeting." "It now seems that labour force data will become more crucial to the RBAs decision making." "The board will be hoping to see some softening in the unemployment rate, to reduce the chance of further pressure on wages." EY's chief economist Cherelle Murphy thinks the fall in inflation over the June quarter is a cause for optimism. "The slowing in the quarterly rates of price growth eases pressure on the Reserve Bank to raise rates again in August, with the data suggesting that its dozen rate hikes since May 2022 are working as planned." "But with inflation still far above the Reserve Bank’s 2-3 per cent target band, and some ongoing upside risks to wages and food prices, we are not out of the danger zone yet." Stephen Smith from Deloitte Access Economics thinks the Reserve Bank has gone too far in increasing borrowing costs. "Excessive inflation in Australia has mostly been caused by supply side factors, meaning that interest rate increases have mostly been ineffective at bringing inflation under control. "Rather, inflation has fallen as a result of repairs to global supply chains and an easing of import prices. "The Australian economy is softening dramatically, the pace of inflation has peaked and is moderating quickly, wage growth is not excessive and medium-term inflation expectations are not rising." However, Jarden chief economist Carlos Carlos told Alicia Barry on the ABC News Channel that he thinks the official cash rate could go to 4.6 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: To hike or not hike: that is the question

children.content: While the market is betting on a 70 per cent chance of rates staying on hold next week at 4.1 per cent because of cooling inflation, economists are torn.
Nomura Australia's Andrew Ticehurst thinks the Reserve Bank will put rate hikes on ice for now because of the new data.
"We now think this will provide the RBA with sufficient ammunition to deliver another “pause” at its policy meeting next week."
"However, we are reluctant to call the end of the hiking cycle at this point,
and think it appropriate for the market to price in another 0.25 per cent of hikes over coming months, on a balance-of-risks basis."
CreditorWatch chief economist Anneke Thompson
says consumers have well and truly responded to the RBA's tightening measures.
" This result has reduced the chance of a further cash rate rise at the August meeting."
"It now seems that labour force data will become more crucial to the RBAs decision making."
"The board will be hoping to see some softening in the unemployment rate, to reduce the chance of further pressure on wages."
EY's chief economist Cherelle Murphy
thinks the fall in inflation over the June quarter is a cause for optimism.

"The slowing in the quarterly rates of price growth eases pressure on the Reserve Bank to raise rates again in August, with the data suggesting that its dozen rate hikes since May 2022 are working as planned."
"But with inflation still far above the Reserve Bank’s 2-3 per cent target band, and some ongoing upside risks to wages and food prices, we are not out of the danger zone yet."
Stephen Smith from Deloitte Access Economics
thinks the Reserve Bank has gone too far in increasing borrowing costs.
"Excessive inflation in Australia has mostly been caused by supply side factors, meaning that interest rate increases have mostly been ineffective at bringing inflation under control.
"Rather, inflation has fallen as a result of repairs to global supply chains and an easing of import prices.
"The Australian economy is softening dramatically, the pace of inflation has peaked and is moderating quickly, wage growth is not excessive and medium-term inflation expectations are not rising."
However,
Jarden chief economist Carlos Carlos
told Alicia Barry on the ABC News Channel that he thinks the official cash rate could go to 4.6 per cent.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Business group, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the lower than expected price rises are welcome news for small businesses and consumers. It says annual inflation falling to a 12 month low eases pressure on the RBA when it meets next week. “Further cooling of inflation in the June quarter is the latest positive sign that the Reserve Bank’s interest rate rises are having their desired effect on price pressures,” says ACCI chief executive Andrew McKellar. “With falls now coming through, today’s data is encouraging for many small business owners who are now seeing the costs of doing business starting to ease." "Business reiterates its call for the Reserve Bank to hold rates at its August meeting, and take stock of the existing leverage of 12 rate increases since the beginning of the Reserve’s current tightening cycle.” Innes Willox, chief executive of the Australian Industry Group agrees the inflation data is positive. “The lower than expected annual rate of increase in inflation to the end of the March quarter, combined with the recent labour force data, should give some cause for hope that we are on track for a soft landing that retains as many of the recent gains in employment as possible," he says. And Mr Willox is warning that wage increases could add to inflation, concerns that have been echoed by the Reserve Bank, but which are dismissed by unions. “There are no guarantees that the landing will be soft and the path remains a narrow one." "It therefore remains critical that continued restraint is exercised by business, governments and employees in price setting and wage negotiations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business also calls for rates  pause

children.content: Business group, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the lower than expected price rises are welcome news for small businesses and consumers.
It says annual inflation falling to a 12 month low eases pressure on the RBA when it meets next week.
“Further cooling of inflation in the June quarter is the latest positive sign that the Reserve Bank’s interest rate rises are having their desired effect on price pressures,” says
ACCI chief executive Andrew McKellar.
“With falls now coming through, today’s data is encouraging for many small business owners who are now seeing the costs of doing business starting to ease."

"Business reiterates its call for the Reserve Bank to hold rates at its August meeting, and take stock of the existing leverage of 12 rate increases since the beginning of the Reserve’s current tightening cycle.”
Innes Willox, chief executive of the Australian Industry Group agrees the inflation data is positive.

“The lower than expected annual rate of increase in inflation to the end of the March quarter, combined with the recent labour force data, should give some cause for hope that we are on track for a soft landing that retains as many of the recent gains in employment as possible," he says.
And Mr Willox is warning that wage increases could add to inflation, concerns that have been echoed by the Reserve Bank, but which are dismissed by unions.
“There are no guarantees that the landing will be soft and the path remains a narrow one."
"It therefore remains critical that continued restraint is exercised by business, governments and employees in price setting and wage negotiations."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Council of Trade Unions wants the Reserve Bank to put interest rate increases on hold because of the drop in inflation. They note real wages are not keeping up with the cost of living and household budgets remain under pressure. Over the year, rents increased by 6.7 per cent, utilities rose nearly 14 per cent, and bread, milk and cheese prices have all soared. Here's ACTU assistant secretary Joseph Mitchell: “Today’s figures show that family budgets are still under unprecedented pressures with everyday items are eating more out of workers hard earned wages." "Corporate profits are still on the rise with data showing Australia had the third highest growth in profits  in the OECD between 2019 and 2023, indicating big business is price gouging workers through this  crisis." "The RBA should note this fall in inflation and not inflict any more pain on pockets of hard-working  Australians who are just trying to get on with everyday life, yet are being punished for a crisis they  played no part in."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACTU calls for rate hike pause

children.content: The Australian Council of Trade Unions wants the Reserve Bank to put interest rate increases on hold because of the drop in inflation.
They note real wages are not keeping up with the cost of living and household budgets remain under
pressure.
Over the year, rents increased by 6.7 per cent, utilities rose nearly 14 per cent, and bread, milk and cheese prices have all soared.
Here's ACTU assistant secretary Joseph Mitchell:
“Today’s figures show that family budgets are still under unprecedented pressures with everyday items are eating more out of workers hard earned wages."

"Corporate profits are still on the rise with data showing Australia had the third highest growth in profits  in the OECD between 2019 and 2023, indicating big business is price gouging workers through this  crisis."

"The RBA should note this fall in inflation and not inflict any more pain on pockets of hard-working  Australians who are just trying to get on with everyday life, yet are being punished for a crisis they  played no part in."
